review.title: Averaged Hausdorff Approximations of Pareto Fronts based on Multiobjective Estimation of Distribution Algorithms
review.abstract: In the a posteriori approach of multiobjective optimization the Pareto front is approximated by a finite set of solutions in the objective space. The quality of the approximation can be measured by different indicators that take into account the approximation's closeness to the Pareto front and its distribution along the Pareto front. In particular, the averaged Hausdorff indicator prefers an almost uniform distribution. An observed drawback of multiobjective estimation of distribution algorithms (MEDAs) is that - as common for randomized metaheuristics - the final population usually is not uniformly distributed along the Pareto front. Therefore, we propose a postprocessing strategy which consists of applying the averaged Hausdorff indicator to the complete archive of generated solutions after optimization in order to select a uniformly distributed subset of nondominated solutions from the archive. In this paper, we put forward a strategy for extracting the above described subset. The effectiveness of the proposal is contrasted in a series of experiments that involve different MEDAs and filtering techniques.

metadata.title: Averaged Hausdorff Approximations of Pareto Fronts based on Multiobjective Estimation of Distribution Algorithms 2015

sections.text: The quality of the approximation can be measured by various indicators that take into account the proximity of the approximation to the Pareto front and its distribution along the Pareto front. In particular, the average Hausdorff indicator prefers an almost uniform distribution. An observed disadvantage of the multi-objective estimation of distribution algorithms (MEDAs) is that, as is usual in randomized metaheuristics, the final population is not normally evenly distributed along the Pareto front. Therefore, we propose a postprocessing strategy that consists of applying the Hausdorff averaged indicator to the complete archive of generated solutions after optimization in order to select an evenly distributed subset of non-dominated solutions from the archive. In this paper, we propose a strategy for extracting the subset described above. The effectiveness of the proposal is contrasted in a series of experiments involving different MEDAs and filtering techniques.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: In order to experimentally evaluate the ∆ p archive approach for multiple multi-objective EDAs, we implemented two offline strategies within the JAVATM jMetall framework: a forward ∆ p approach (+ fDP), starting with the initial population and iteratively updating with previously tracked generations, whereas the backward strategy (+ bDP) begins with the final population. Finally, within this framework, a solution was added to the archive, a linear interpolation and a PSA-based strategy, both using the aggregated solutions of the entire run, to derive a series of reference points with equal spacing. On this basis, a solution was finally added to the archive system. We then used known MOPs for benchmarking [8]: an instance of the Sphere problem with X R2 and an associated convex pareto front, the DENT problem with X R2 and an associated convex convex-TX and R3 connected front.

sections.heading: 3.2 Results
sections.text: At first glance, the behaviour of the algorithms within the classical EMOA is examined by comparing the MEDAs with the classical EMOA approaches in terms of the indicator Dominated Hypervolume (HV, [4]), which requires significant improvements in terms of the indicator Dominated Hypervolume (HV, [4]) and "p" (Figures 1 and 2), which are based on the primary reference fronts described in Section 3.1. However, it becomes apparent that the MEDAs lead to very stable results over the repeated runs reflected by both indicators, while no MEDA is superior to the others. Furthermore, the respective performance for all test strategies is comparable to the best performing algorithms outside the classical EMOA set. While for all test problems, but WFG1 PSEMOA and SCD-NSGA2 can be considered best in terms of p, SMS-EMOA exceeds the other classical EMOA strategies in terms of HV optimization.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text: In this work, we first compared the quality of the solutions of four evolutionary multi-objective optimization algorithms (NSGA2, PSEMOA, SCD-NSGA2, SMS-EMOA) and four multi-objective distribution algorithms (MARTEDA, MO-CMA-ES, MONEDA, Naive MIDEA) using a number of well-known multi-objective test problems. Based on two indicators considered - HV and ∆ p - it was shown that the performance of MEDAs at least competes with that of classical EMOAs. MEDAs themselves also developed quite similarly. Based on these competitive and therefore promising results, we analyzed whether the performance of the latter with respect to ∆ p could even be improved by a subsequent application of forward or backward actualization strategies that lead to a more even distribution of solutions along the approximated Pareto front. Experiments confirmed this hypothesis and the apparent influence of the use of these two updating directions.
